intro: Primula boothii subsp. autumnalis, commonly known as the autumn primrose, is a herbaceous perennial native to the mountainous regions of central Asia. It typically grows to a height of 10–30 cm, featuring lance-shaped leaves with a slightly hairy surface. The plant produces clusters of small, bell-shaped flowers in shades of white, pink, and purple, which bloom in late summer to early autumn. It thrives in cool, moist environments and is often found in meadows and rocky slopes. Due to its ornamental value and ecological significance, it is cultivated in gardens and conservation areas.
